identificationModule.briefTitle: The Study Will Evaluate the Efficacy of AZD5423 in Patients With Mild Asthma Challenged With an Inhaled Allergen
identificationModule.officialTitle: A Double-blind, Double-dummy, Randomised, Placebo-controlled, 4-way, Crossover, Multi-centre Phase II Study With Budesonide as an Active Control to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of 2 Doses of Inhaled AZD5423 Over 7 Days in Patients With Mild Allergic Asthma Challenged With an Inhaled Allergen

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of AZD5423 in patients with mild asthma challenged with an inhaled allergen.

interventions.name: AZD5423
interventions.description: Suspension for nebulisation once daily 7 days

interventions.name: Budesonide 200 microgram
interventions.description: Dry powder for inhalation twice daily 7 days

interventions.name: Placebo
interventions.description: Solution for nebulisation once daily 7 days

interventions.name: Placebo
interventions.description: Solution for nebulisation once daily 7 days

primaryOutcomes.measure: Late Allergic Response (LAR) by Assessment of Minimum Percentage of FEV1 3-7 Hours Post Allergen Challenge Compared to Pre Allergen Challenge FEV1
primaryOutcomes.description: LAR was assessed on Day 6 as minimum percentage of FEV1 over 3 to 7 hours based on the analysis of the minimum percentage of FEV1 remaining over 3 to 7 hours post allergen challenge (post AC) compared to pre allergen challenge (pre AC) FEV1
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: From Randomization to end of treatment

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Early Allergic Response (EAR) by Assessment of Minimum Percentage of FEV1 0-3 h Post Allergen Challenge
secondaryOutcomes.description: Minimum Percentage of FEV1 over 0 to 3 hours post allergen challenge compared to pre allergen challenge FEV1
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: From Randomization to end of treatment

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Area Under the Curve (AUC) for FEV1 Over 0-3 and 3-7 h Post Allergen Challenge
secondaryOutcomes.description: AUC was assessed as average percentage of FEV1 remaining 0 to 3 hours and 3 to 7 hours post allergen challenge compared to pre allergen challenge FEV1
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: From Randomization to end of treatment

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Airway Hyperresponsiveness by Assessment of Methacholine PC20
secondaryOutcomes.description: The methacholine challenge was performed on Day 1 (pre dose), Day 5 (\[post dose\] pre AC), and Day 7 (\[post dose\] 24 hours post AC)

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Airway Hyperresponsiveness by Assessment of Methacholine PC20
secondaryOutcomes.description: The methacholine challenge was performed on Day 1 (pre dose), Day 5 (\[post dose\] pre AC), and Day 7 (\[post dose\] 24 hours post AC)

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Airway Hyperresponsiveness by Assessment of Methacholine PC20
secondaryOutcomes.description: The methacholine challenge was performed on Day 1 (pre dose), Day 5 (\[post dose\] pre AC), and Day 7 (\[post dose\] 24 hours post AC)

The change form baseline in percentage of sputum eosinophils was assessed on Day 5 (post dose) ,Day 6 (\[post dose\] 7 hours post allergen challenge) and Day 7 (\[post dose\] 24 hours post allergen challenge)

The change form baseline in percentage of sputum eosinophils was assessed on Day 5 (post dose) ,Day 6 (\[post dose\] 7 hours post allergen challenge) and Day 7 (\[post dose\] 24 hours post allergen challenge)
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Day 6 ([post dose] 7 hours post allergen challenge)

secondaryOutcomes.description: The change form baseline in percentage of sputum eosinophils was assessed on Day 5 (post dose) ,Day 6 (\[post dose\] 7 hours post allergen challenge) and Day 7 (\[post dose\] 24 hours post allergen challenge)
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Day 7 ([post dose] 24 hours post allergen challenge)

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* 18-60 years of age
* Pre-bronchodilatory FEV1 ≥70% of predicted normal allergic asthmatic with a history of episodic wheeze
* Positive allergen induced early and late airway bronchoconstriction showing ≥ 20% fall in FEV1 for the early and ≥ 15% for the late response
* Positive skin prick test to common aeroallergens

Exclusion Criteria:

* Any clinically significant disease or disorder
* Any clinically relevant abnormal finding at screening examinations
* Smoker or ex-smoker who has stopped smoking \< 12 months prior to study start
* Worsening of asthma or respiratory infection within 6 weeks from visit 1
* Allergen-specific immunotherapy within 6 months prior to visit 1

references.citation: Gauvreau GM, Boulet LP, Leigh R, Cockcroft DW, Killian KJ, Davis BE, Deschesnes F, Watson RM, Swystun V, Mardh CK, Wessman P, Jorup C, Aurivillius M, O'Byrne PM. A nonsteroidal glucocorticoid receptor agonist inhibits allergen-induced late asthmatic responses. Am J Respir Crit Care Med. 2015 Jan 15;191(2):161-7. doi: 10.1164/rccm.201404-0623OC.

participantFlowModule.preAssignmentDetails: Total 27 patients enrolled, 20 (74.1%) patients were randomised to receive a treatment sequence consisting of 4 different treatment in random order. From 20 randomised patients, 18 (90%) patients completed the study and 2 (10%) patients were withdrawn from the study due to consumption of disallowed medication
participantFlowModule.recruitmentDetails: Patients were enrolled from 4 centres in the AllerGen CIC group in Canada.

limitationsAndCaveats.description: Of the 27 patients enrolled, 20 (74.1%) patient were randomised to receive a treatment sequence consisting of 4 different treatment in random order. 19 patients completed each individual treatment period and 17 patients completed all 4 treatment

certainAgreement.otherDetails: PI shall not publish any results until (i) the date of the first Study results publication, or in case of a Multi-Centre Study the first Multi-Centre Results publication, agreed by the participating sites, and (ii) the end of the eighteen (18) month period following the completion or early termination of the Study at all participating sites.

ancestors.term: Hormones, Hormone Substitutes, and Hormone Antagonists
